answers: drunken [accept equivalents such as intoxicated or inebriated; accept A Drunk Man Looks at the Thistle]
Scotland [prompt on U.K. or United Kingdom]
parts: Give this state of being. A character who is often in this state of being names a style of men’s bonnet and exclaims “Well done, Cutty-sark!” upon seeing some witches dance at a sabbath.
The author of “Tam o’ Shanter” also wrote this poem that is often set to music and used as a drinking song. It asks “should old acquaintance be forgot, and never brought to mind?”
“Tam o’ Shanter” and “Auld Lang Syne” were written in the language of this country by its national poet, Robert Burns.
Name these particles whose six flavors have charges equal to two-thirds and negative-one-third of the elementary charge.

A quark and antiquark form these particles, which are both the lightest mesons and lightest hadrons. The Hagedorn (“HA-guh-dorn”) temperature at which matter is believed to evaporate or convert into quark matter equals the mass-energy of these particles.

This hypothetical exotic meson is predicted by the standard model to have a total angular momentum of either 2 or 3 in the ground state. These hard-to-validate particles are formed entirely of the carrier of the strong force.

answers: cloth [or textiles; or fabrics; or clothing; prompt on cotton or flax]
seashells [or sea snail shells; or shell money; or cowrie shells]
parts: Identify this type of good. Other African examples of this type of good include the kente variety made by the Akan people.
Another medium of exchange in the Kongo kingdom was the nzimbu, a type of these objects. The Portuguese flooded the market for these items by importing them in bulk from the Indian Ocean.
The Akan people also made brass figurines to measure precise amounts of this precious metal. The massive Holtermann Nugget was found during a mania for this metal in Australia in the 1850s.

answers: The Incoherence of the Philosophers [or Tahafut al-Falasifah] (by al-Ghazali)
Thomas Aquinas [or Tomasso d’Aquino; prompt on Saint Thomas]
parts: Name this relentless attack on Avicenna’s philosophy which argues that several doctrines derived from Aristotle and Plato amount to “unbelief” in Islam.

Avicenna legendarily read this Aristotle text forty times without understanding it until he read al-Farabi’s commentary. This book on “first philosophy” delineates material, formal, efficient, and final causes.
Averroes (“ah-VAIR-oh-eez”) is cited for his commentaries on the Metaphysics in the Summa Theologica, which is by this medieval scholastic philosopher.

answers: castrati [or castrato; accept castrated singers or equivalents; prompt on eunuchs or countertenors]
C6 (“C-six”) [accept informal terms such as soprano C or high C; do not accept anything that is explicitly not C6, such as “C5”]
parts: Name these male opera singers who could hit high notes because doctors removed their genitals before they hit puberty.

Farinelli could hit this highest note that sopranos were asked to sing at the time. Since then, soprano arias have occasionally ventured higher, such as with the high Fs in Mozart’s “Der Hölle Rache (“dair HUR-luh RAH-khuh”).”
This composer used female travesti roles for Tancredi to imitate the sound of castrati. One of his comic operas features the iconic aria “Largo al factotum.”

answers: whether or not the Qur’an is created [or whether or not the Qur’an is eternal; or whether or not the Qur’an is pre-existent; accept any answer mentioning the words created or uncreated or eternal or pre-exist but do not accept any answer that does not use one of these words]
parts: Name this debate about the Qur’an, for which al-Ma’mun organized the Mihna as an inquisition to enforce the teachings of the rationalistic Mu‘tazilites. A descriptive answer is necessary.
The name of this branch of Islam comes from the body of Muhammad’s practices. Members of this largest branch of Islam reject the createdness of the Qur’an, unlike most Shia.
Ibn Hanbal founded one of the four Sunni madhhabs (“math-HABS”), or schools of thought in this field of Islamic jurisprudence that interprets the meaning of Sharia law.

answers: BLAST [or Basic Local Alignment Search Tool]
homologous [accept homology or homologous sequences or homologous structures]
parts: Name this algorithm used for sequence alignment of DNA and proteins. This algorithm uses FASTA files as input and is run by the NCBI.

BLAST can be used to assess whether or not two sequences have this quality. The pentadactyl limb found in humans and other vertebrates has this quality, which means that it was derived from a shared common ancestor.
The existence of homologous structures implies that this type of evolution has occurred. This type of evolution leads to speciation.
Identify this ancient law code promulgated by a king of the First Babylonian dynasty.

The text in the Stele of the Code of Hammurabi is written in this language, also known as Assyro-Babylonian. Since 1921, the University of Chicago has published a dictionary of this East Semitic language.

Fragments of Hammurabi’s Code have been found in this city, whose “scribal corner” is rich with ancient texts. Various Mesopotamian dynasties sought to control this city of religious importance, the home of the god Enlil.

answers: Frida Kahlo [or Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderón]
column [or Ionic column; or The Broken Column; or La Columna Rota; or pillar]
parts: Identify this animal that hangs from a thorn necklace in a self-portrait that also depicts a monkey, cat, and butterfly.
Self-Portrait with Thorn Necklace and Hummingbird is a painting by this Mexican artist who often depicted herself with a unibrow.
Another Kahlo self-portrait allegorizes her chronic pain from a bus accident by replacing her spine with a broken one of these objects.
Identify this title activity that causes the speaker to dream a dream where “the ladder sways as the boughs (“bows”) bend.”
“After Apple Picking” is a poem by this author of the collection North of Boston who wrote “Mending Wall.”
The narrator of this Robert Frost poem envisions the title trees as having been bent “to left and right” because “some boy’s been swinging them.”

answers: Cassini-Huygens [or ASI/NASA Cassini orbiter; or Cassini probe]
rings of Saturn [or Saturn’s rings; prompt on rings]
Roche limit [or Roche radius; do not accept or prompt on “Roche lobe”]
parts: Name this probe that was “de-orbited” to avoid contaminating any water-bearing moons. This probe’s inclined orbits allowed a final look at a distinct polar feature during its Grand Finale.

Debate over the age of these objects was fueled by data gathered as the Grand Finale passed between them and their parent planet. The Cassini probe shares its namesake with a division between the A and B examples of these objects.
Saturn’s rings were formed from moons that were torn apart because they lay inside this boundary, inside which satellites are destroyed by tidal forces.

answers: Costa Rica [or Republic of Costa Rica]
parts: Identify this Latin American country that abolished its military in 1948.

Costa Rica absorbed many refugees from this other Central American country during the Sandinista war. The Iran-Contra affair involved the US government selling weapons to rebels in this country, whose capital is Managua.

This man reinstated slavery during his brief rule of Nicaragua starting in 1856. During his rule, he gave control of Accessory Transit Company assets to C. K. Garrison and Charles Morgan, attracting the ire of Cornelius Vanderbilt.

answers: Ra [or Re or Amun or Atum or combinations thereof]
parts: In the myth, Thoth allowed the sky goddess to give birth by winning at dice against Khonsu, who repeatedly wagered this substance.
This sky goddess, the wife of Geb, gave birth to one child on each of the extra days won by Thoth. The first child this goddess gave birth to was the fertility god Osiris.
The extra days were needed because this sun god had forbidden Nut from bearing children during any month of the year.

answers: independent AND identically distributed [or i.i.d.; prompt on partial answer; prompt on uncorrelated]
expected value [or expectation; or EV; prompt on E; prompt on average or arithmetic mean; do not accept or prompt on “mean”]
normal distribution [accept Gaussian distribution or Laplace–Gauss distribution]
parts: Name these frequently paired assumptions that are violated by time series. Sufficiently long sequences of variables obeying these two assumptions have the characteristic function e to the negative one-half t-squared.

The law of large numbers states that the mean of i.i.d. variables converges to this value. In the continuous case, this value is the integral over the range of x times the probability density function of x.
The central limit theorem predicts that a sample mean of i.i.d. variables will follow this bell-shaped distribution.

answers: fireflies [or lightning bugs; or glow-worms; prompt on insects]
parts: Identify this literary character whose death is implied in the “Vanished into the Clouds” section of a book titled after him.
The Tale of Genji is a literary treasure from this Asian country.
In a chapter of The Tale of Genji titled for these things, Genji releases these things to allow Prince Hotaru to see the face of the young woman Tamakazura, who has been rejecting Genji’s advances.
Name this northernmost major battle of the Civil War. It ended after Pickett’s Charge led to heavy Confederate casualties on July 3rd, 1863.
On the second day of the battle, Confederate troops under James Longstreet attempted to flank the Union army by attacking this hill on the end of Cemetery Ridge.

This Union Colonel received a Medal of Honor for his leadership of the 20th Maine infantry at Little Round Top. After his troops ran out of bullets, he ordered a bayonet charge that broke Confederate lines.

answers: United Kingdom [or UK; or England; or Great Britain; or Scotland]
Ralph Vaughan Williams (“rayf von williams”) [prompt on partial answer]
parts: Name this country whose folk music scene was revived by Australian-born composer Percy Grainger with arrangements of Morris dancing songs like “Country Gardens.”
Richard King’s chronicle of English pastoral music, The Lark Ascending, takes its title from a piece by this composer of Sinfonia antarctica.

Richard King traces idyllic English music from Vaughan Williams to this annual festival held in Somerset. The psychedelic folk act “T. Rex” played at the first iteration of this event, when it was then called the Pilton Pop, Blues & Folk Festival.

answers: Palm Beach County [do not accept or prompt on “West Palm Beach”]
parts: Identify this state where a Buc-ee’s is located at the intersection of I-35 West and SH 114 in Fort Worth.
This state is home to the first United Dairy Farmers convenience store and the first Wendy’s. This state’s capital sits at the confluence of the Olentangy and Scioto (“sy-OH-tuh”) rivers.

Pennsylvania’s Wawa chain has recently branched out to this Florida county, where the Affordable Care Act spawned a bonanza in sober living centers. Boynton Beach is in this county, which is located due north of Broward County.

answers: The Human Comedy [or La Comédie humaine]
parts: Name this series whose short stories include “Facino Cane” and “The Unknown Masterpiece.” The title character befriends a panther he nicknames “Mignon” in its story “The Passion in the Desert.”
Balzac championed this literary movement that spawned the later naturalism movement. This movement focused on “the presentation of credible experiences and happenings in literature.”
This philosopher argued that Balzac’s apparent realism was in fact “copying a (depicted) copy of the real.” He examined professional wrestling in an essay in his collection Mythologies.

regular [accept regular grammars or regular languages or regular expressions; accept regex]
parts: Give this type of grammar referred to as Type-1 in a hierarchy where Type-0 refers to any recursively-enumerable grammar.
That hierarchy of grammars is named for this MIT linguist who developed the theory of Universal Grammar.

Grammars described by this word are Type-3 in the hierarchy. Grammars described by this word can be modeled with finite state automata as well as by “expressions” described by this word that are used in computer science to match patterns in strings.

answers: Mexico [or United Mexican States; or UMS; or Estados Unidos Mexicanos]
parts: Identify this genre of the texts which serve as epigraphs for a 1989 novel by Laura Esquivel.

In Like Water for Chocolate, Tita bakes a vomit-inducing cake, but cooks much better food for the wedding of this daughter of Rosaura. A different character with this first name begrudgingly looks after her sister Nenny in The House on Mango Street.
Tita’s family lives in the north of this country. Children and parents leaving this country for one to the north are separated from each other in Valeria Luiselli’s 2019 novel Lost Children Archive.
